Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Measuring the thermal tolerances of individuals, populations, and species and predicting plant species' responses to climate change in the tropical Andes
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most basic questions in ecology is: Where does each species occur? And following on that: What environmental factors determine where a particular species occurs? Despite the seeming simplicity of these questions, they remain unanswered for the vast majority of species. This lack of knowledge is especially troubling given the implications for understanding how species will respond to climate change through either shifts in where they occur or through physiological adaptations. This study will address these and other questions through a series of experimental and observational studies conducted in the Andean mountains of Peru, where many species are unusually vulnerable to small changes in temperature and rainfall. More specifically, the project will measure altitudinal ranges and thermal tolerances of nearly two dozen cloud forest tree species. The investigators will also determine the extent to which small populations of each species are tightly adapted to particular elevations ("local adaptation") and each species' ability to change its thermal tolerance ("plasticity"). Data will be incorporated into models designed to predict where species currently occur and where they might start to occur as climates change.

This project is one of the first to systematically test several key assumptions critical to the assessment how climate change will impact where species are able to live. It will be the first-ever study to simultaneously measure the thermal tolerances of individuals, populations, and species of tropical trees. The results will greatly expand our understanding of the complex factors determining where species occur, and will strengthen our ability to predict species responses to future climate change.

The research will be integrated with an extensive set of educational, training, and outreach programs in collaboration with established domestic and international environmental education organizations. Outreach programs are designed to help increase the participation of US minorities and international students in the biological sciences, and to broaden public awareness of the potential impacts of climate change on tropical forests around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most basic and fundamental questions in ecology is "Where do species occur"?, and following on that, "Why does this species occur in these places and not in other places"?  Despite the seeming simplicity of these questions, they remain unanswered for the vast majority of species. This lack of knowledge is especially troubling given the clear need to understand how species will respond to climate change through either changes in where they occur (i.e., 'species migrations') or through their ability tolerate different environmental conditions through acclimation and/or adaptation.  With the support of the US National Science Foundation, KJ Feeley and his colleagues addressed these and other related questions through a series of experimental and observational studies conducted in the tropical Andes Mountains of Peru and Colombia - two of the most diverse places on the planet.

First, the project team used botanical field surveys and analyses of herbarium records to map the geographic range of many tropical tree species.  By repeatedly mapping the ranges of species over different time periods, it was shown that most species are 'migrating' to higher elevations as global temperatures increase. Of note, however, was the finding that many species are either migrating too slow to maintain equilibrium with climate or they are experiences rapid range contractions as they 'die back' from the parts of their ranges that are becoming too hot and fail to expand into newly suitable areas.  As a consequence of these changes in species' distributions, the composition of forest communities and ecosystems are rapidly changing through time, such that heat-loving species are generally becoming more abundant.  In many cases, the new communities are 'novel' and have no analog to the mixes of species that previously existed in these forests.

Next, the team measured suites of traits to determine the physiological tolerances of tropical tree species to cold, heat, and drought.  By combining these physiological measures with the distribution maps, it was revealed that most species can in fact tolerate much harsher conditions than they typically experience in their current ranges.  This suggests that most species' distributions are determined by species interactions.  In other words, in the absence of competition, many species could potentially tolerate climate change without shifting their distributions.  

To explore this idea further, the team conducted a set of transplant experiments.  These experiments compared the performance of plants that grow in the newly suitable areas (in which case temperature will be equivalent to where they live today but soils will change) vs. plants that continue to grow in their current location (in which case soils will remain the same but temperatures will be elevated).  To emphasize the importance of these questions for human livelihoods, the transplants were replicated using trees in their natural habits and crop plants (maize and potatoes) in managed agricultural settings. In both cases, we found that species will suffer if they continue growing where they do today, but that the decline in performance will be due more to increased herbivory and pest loads than to direct temperature stress. In contrast, changes in soils will pose relatively little challenge to species 'migrating' into higher elevations.  

These represent some of the first studies to systematically test several key assumptions critical to the assessment of the potential impacts of climate change on species' distributions.  These studies greatly expand our understanding of the complex factors that determine where tropical tree species occur and also our ability to predict these species' responses to future climate change.  This research, as supported by the NSF, resulted in more than 30 peer-reviewed publications - many in high impact journals.

Coupled with the research, KJ Feeley and his collaborators at the Amazon Center for Environmental Education and Research (ACEER) and the Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden (FTBG) developed an integrated set of educational, training, and outreach programs in Peru and Miami, USA.  These outreach programs helped to increase the participation of US minorities and international students in the biological sciences, and to broaden public awareness of the potential impacts of climate change on tropical forests.
